name_origin.etymology: The name 'Banatage' (or Banatache) is likely a linguistic corruption of the Spanish/Ladino word 'Empanada' (or the archaic 'Panada'), filtered through Tunisian Arabic phonology. In Arabic, the letter 'P' does not exist and is often replaced by 'B' (e.g., 'Pepsi' becomes 'Bebsi'). Therefore, 'Empanada' became 'Mbanada' or 'Banada'. The suffix '-age' or '-ej' likely reflects a Maghrebi pluralization or a French colonial phonetic influence on the ending. Historically, 'Banadhej' appears in medieval Andalusian-Maghrebi cookbooks referring to small stuffed pies. The Djerban Jewish innovation was substituting the wheat dough with a potato-based dough (likely for Passover/Pesach compliance), while retaining the name for 'stuffed vessel'.
name_origin.meaning: Literally 'breaded' or 'enbreaded' (originally referring to dough-wrapped items)
name_origin.sources_notes: Linguistic shift P -> B is standard in Judeo-Arabic. The dish is culinarily identical to 'Papas Rellenas' but carries a name derived from dough-based pastries, supporting the theory that it is a Passover adaptation of a flour-based pastel.

similar_dishes.name: Ma'aqouda
similar_dishes.key_difference: Ma'aqouda is usually a flat omelet/fritter mixed with herbs, rarely stuffed with a distinct meat center like Banatage

similar_dishes.name: Kibbeh Batata
similar_dishes.similarity: Mashed potato dough stuffed with spiced ground meat and fried
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses Middle Eastern spices (baharat) and often includes bulgur in the shell; Banatage uses turmeric/pepper and pure potato

similar_dishes.name: Papas Rellenas
similar_dishes.similarity: Identical concept: mashed potato dough stuffed with picadillo (meat) and fried
similar_dishes.key_difference: Fillings differ (raisins/olives in Spanish version vs. savory chicken/turmeric in Djerban)

similar_dishes.name: Pastel
similar_dishes.key_difference: Pastels use a flour/pastry dough; Banatage is the potato equivalent (often for Passover)
